પછી ઘોડે થયા અસવાર<RHYME_213528>, આવ્યા સાંકર્દા ગામ મોઝાર<RHYME_213528>.
gujarati.context:
Here is a summary of the couplet:

Teaching all has ended, and Vadora's play has been finished; Then horses were let out, and we returned to our village Moza.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૯: શ્રીહરિચરિત્રે ગઢડે જન્માષ્ટમી ઉત્સવ કરીને વડોદરા પધાર્યા ને ઘણું ઐશ્વર્ય જણાવ્યું ત્યાંથી વરતાલ પધાર્યા ને ત્યાં શિક્ષાપત્રી લખી
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 99: Shrī Haricharitre Gaḍhaḍe Janmāṣhṭamī Utsav Karīne Vaḍodarā padhāryā ne ghaṇu aishvarya jaṇāvyu tyāthī Vartāl Padhāryā ne Tyā Shikṣhāpatrī Lakhī

gujarati.couplet:
ત્યાંથી વાલો આવ્યા વરતાલ<RHYME_213467>, કરી લીલા અલૌકિક લાલ<RHYME_213467>; 
દોઢ માસ લગી તિયાં રહ્યા, નિજ સંબંધી ગઢડે ગયા.
gujarati.context:
Here is a summary of the couplet:

A guest arrived at their place, bringing joy and celebration; they stayed for two months, strengthening their bond like a fortress.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૯: શ્રીહરિચરિત્રે ગઢડે જન્માષ્ટમી ઉત્સવ કરીને વડોદરા પધાર્યા ને ઘણું ઐશ્વર્ય જણાવ્યું ત્યાંથી વરતાલ પધાર્યા ને ત્યાં શિક્ષાપત્રી લખી
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 99: Shrī Haricharitre Gaḍhaḍe Janmāṣhṭamī Utsav Karīne Vaḍodarā padhāryā ne ghaṇu aishvarya jaṇāvyu tyāthī Vartāl Padhāryā ne Tyā Shikṣhāpatrī Lakhī

gujarati.couplet:
પછી શિક્ષાપત્રી લખી સારી, આપી સતસંગીને સુખકારી; 
ત્યાંથી પધાર્યા સુંદર શ્યામ<RHYME_213482>, ગુણસાગર ગઢડે ગામ<RHYME_213482>.
gujarati.context: After acquiring knowledge and wisdom, one becomes delightful company for others, bringing happiness to those around; thus, the beautiful and virtuous Shyam is born in the world.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૯: શ્રીહરિચરિત્રે ગઢડે જન્માષ્ટમી ઉત્સવ કરીને વડોદરા પધાર્યા ને ઘણું ઐશ્વર્ય જણાવ્યું ત્યાંથી વરતાલ પધાર્યા ને ત્યાં શિક્ષાપત્રી લખી
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 99: Shrī Haricharitre Gaḍhaḍe Janmāṣhṭamī Utsav Karīne Vaḍodarā padhāryā ne ghaṇu aishvarya jaṇāvyu tyāthī Vartāl Padhāryā ne Tyā Shikṣhāpatrī Lakhī

gujarati.couplet:
કર્યો ઉત્સવ એમ જીવને, કારતિક વદિ ત્રીજ દને; 
તે દિ કરી વડોદરે લીલા, હતા સંત સતસંગી ભેળા.
gujarati.context: The festival of life was celebrated with great joy and fervor, just like Kartik vadi tirtha, a sacred day in Gujarat. The city of Vadodara was filled with the joyous sound of people gathered together.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૯: શ્રીહરિચરિત્રે ગઢડે જન્માષ્ટમી ઉત્સવ કરીને વડોદરા પધાર્યા ને ઘણું ઐશ્વર્ય જણાવ્યું ત્યાંથી વરતાલ પધાર્યા ને ત્યાં શિક્ષાપત્રી લખી
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 99: Shrī Haricharitre Gaḍhaḍe Janmāṣhṭamī Utsav Karīne Vaḍodarā padhāryā ne ghaṇu aishvarya jaṇāvyu tyāthī Vartāl Padhāryā ne Tyā Shikṣhāpatrī Lakhī

transliteration.couplet:
Tyār pachhī je je thayu, kahu sāmbhaḷo sahu daī man; <RHYME_1>
Asurāṇ jorāṇ jaktamā, maḷī pīḍiyā harijan.  <RHYME_1>
transliteration.context:
The couplet describes a person who has finally found peace after struggling with their emotions, and they have come to realize that the divine is within them.

Their worries have ceased, and they have obtained inner happiness.

transliteration.couplet:
Pāpī maḷī pariyāṇiyā, harijan haṇavā het; <RHYME_2>
Tenī sahāy karī Hari, kharī rītashu raṇakhet.  <RHYME_2>
transliteration.context: A sinner's path is fraught with troubles, and only God can provide solace; May God be our helper in this chaotic world.

transliteration.couplet:
Duṣhṭ raṇmā daḷiyā, asurpati ati jeh; <RHYME_3>
Bār āgaḷ base pūrā, tarta bhāgyā teh.  <RHYME_3>
transliteration.context:
Here is a summary of the couplet:

One's own flaws can lead to great trouble, while another's blessings are wasted.

The speaker emphasizes that one should first take care of their own shortcomings before seeking external benefits or blaming others for their misfortunes.

transliteration.couplet:
Bhūmino bhār utāriyo, Shrāvaṇ sudi dashamī dane; <RHYME_4>
Te di asur māriyā, Hari ichchhāethī harijane.  <RHYME_4>
transliteration.context: The monsoon rains bring relief from the scorching heat on Dashami day in Shravana month, and evil forces are subdued by Lord Vishnu's will. The devotee's prayers to God are answered with devotion and faith.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī āvyo Aṣhṭamīno dan, teḍyā utsav par munijan; <RHYME_5>
Āvyā satsangī sarave maḷī, Aṣhṭamīno samaiyo sāmbhaḷī.  <RHYME_5>
transliteration.context: The festival of Ashthami is celebrated with great enthusiasm, and it's a time for spiritual gatherings. On this day, all devotees come together to worship and seek blessings.

transliteration.couplet:
Āvī lāgyā Prabhujīne pāy, nīrkhī Nāthne tṛupt na thāy; <RHYME_6>
Vāle bolāvyā mīṭhe vayaṇe, vaḷī joyu amṛut nayaṇe.  <RHYME_6>
transliteration.context: The devotees attain the Lord's grace when they become pure of heart, and their souls are united with God without any intermediaries. The sweet words of the divine messenger bring eternal bliss to those who listen with a pure soul.

transliteration.couplet:
Teṇe karī haryā jan tāp, karyā sukhī alabele āp; <RHYME_7>
Pachhī Aṣhṭamī utsav kīdho, sahu janne ānand dīdho.  <RHYME_7>
transliteration.context: Someone who has done good deeds in the past will face difficulties initially, but ultimately enjoy happiness; similarly, someone who knows the true joy of Aṣhṭamī festival will be filled with delight.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī padhāriyā Varatāl, karavā līlā alaukik lāl; <RHYME_8>
Suṇī āvyā satasangī sahu, teh vinā bījā lok bahu.  <RHYME_8>
transliteration.context:
The couplet describes a divine play that transcends the ordinary world, where one's spiritual journey begins with listening to the holy gathering and finding the seed of truth within.

The ultimate goal is to understand the eternal truths beyond worldly limitations, found through devotional gatherings and self-reflection.

transliteration.couplet:
Āvī lāge Prabhujīne pāy, karī darshan prasanna thāy; <RHYME_9>
Nitya navī kare vālo vāt, suṇī sahu thāy raḷiyāt.  <RHYME_9>
transliteration.context: The Lord is pleased when the devotee arrives at His doorstep with a happy heart; the wind of devotion blows constantly, making the soul joyful and free.

transliteration.couplet:
Vaḷī Lakṣhmīnārāyaṇ jeh, Vāsudev ne Shrī Kṛuṣhṇa teh; <RHYME_10>
Tenī mūratine nitya nitya, diye pradakṣhiṇā karī prītya.  <RHYME_10>
transliteration.context: Vaishnavas like Lakshminarayan and Vasudev worship Krishna, who is the embodiment of eternal love and joy. Their daily rituals are filled with devotion and bliss, as they lovingly circumambulate their beloved deity.

transliteration.couplet:
Diye prakramā te doya shat, pachhī kare pāch danḍavat; <RHYME_11>
Em karatā vītyā mās doy, āvyo dīp utsav din soy.  <RHYME_11>
transliteration.context: A person's wealth is spent in youth, and in old age, their reputation is what remains. In one's life, there are celebrations of joy and sorrow.

transliteration.couplet:
Pūrī dīpamāḷā shobhe ghaṇu, jāṇyu mandir baṇyu maṇi taṇu; <RHYME_12>
Joī jan thayā chhe chakit, lāge pāy karī bahu prīt.  <RHYME_12>
transliteration.context:
The couplet describes a heart that shines like a lamp (pūrī dīpamāḷā), and the speaker's joy is so immense that it feels like a temple built with precious stones.

Note: The second line has a wordplay on "chakit" which means both "who is this?" and "who is he?", emphasizing the intensity of the speaker's emotions.

transliteration.couplet:
Kare darshan nar ne nārya, mukhe bole jay jaykār; <RHYME_13>
Vītyo utsav vaḷate dane, pūryo Annakoṭ bahu anne.  <RHYME_13>
transliteration.context: A devotee has a glimpse of God's glory and rejoices saying "Victory to the Lord". The celebration is filled with the joy of spiritual offerings, where countless people are filled with devotion.

transliteration.couplet:
Jamyā Nāth jamāḍiyā jan, pote pīrasyu thaī prasanna; <RHYME_14>
Em āpe chhe sukh apār, nitya pratye te prāṇ-ādhār.  <RHYME_14>
transliteration.context: The seeker of truth is blessed when they are united with their Lord, and their heart is filled with joy. In that state, they find eternal peace and their soul is rooted in divine devotion.

transliteration.couplet:
Em karatā Prabodhanī āvī, Ekādashī janaman bhāvī; <RHYME_15>
Te di utsav karyo anup, sarve santne je sukhrūp.  <RHYME_15>
transliteration.context: The moment of enlightenment arrives when one is reborn on Ekadashi, a sacred day. On this day, all auspicious ceremonies are held with joy and happiness.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī vītyā thoḍā ghaṇā dan, karyu Vaḍodare jāvā man; <RHYME_16>
Vaḍodare padharāvyā kāje, lakhyā kāgaḷ te bahu rāje.  <RHYME_16>
transliteration.context: In times of scarcity, people's minds are elsewhere, but when abundance arrives, it brings prosperity and many joys. Abundance makes the world flourish, bringing happiness to many.

transliteration.couplet:
Kahe ekvār āvo āhī, vālā Vaḍodarā shaher māhi; <RHYME_17>
Mane darshan diyo dayāḷ, dīnbandhu dīnpratipāḷ.  <RHYME_17>
transliteration.context:
When the river of life runs dry, one seeks solace in the city of Ahmedabad; 
May I be granted a glimpse of compassion and comfort from my dear friend in need.

transliteration.couplet:
Ekvār karu darashan, nathī bījī ichchhā māre man; <RHYME_18>
Āvo āhī lagī tame Nāth, nahi to āvīsh hu joḍī hāth.  <RHYME_18>
transliteration.context: The speaker longs for a glimpse of the divine, and their soul's yearning is crushed by the absence; if they don't get it, their hands are empty.

transliteration.couplet:
Tyāre Mahārāje mūkiyu kahāvī, deshu darshan tamane āvī; <RHYME_19>
Pachhī padhāryā sundar Shyām, āvī ūtaryā Sānkarde gām.  <RHYME_19>
transliteration.context: The king of the region, Tyāre Mahārāje, came to visit and was delighted by the beautiful scenery; subsequently, he was taken to see the lovely Shyām.

transliteration.couplet:
Karī rasoī jamāḍyā Nāth, jamyā sakhā hatā jeh sāth; <RHYME_20>
Jamī poḍhiyā Shyām saneh, vuṭho māvaṭhe āvī tyā meh.  <RHYME_20>
transliteration.context: Lord Krishna's love is as deep as the ocean, and his companion Radha's bond with him is as strong as a tree trunk. His sweet memories are stored in his heart like treasures in a treasure box.

transliteration.couplet:
Thayu savār sadhāvyā Shyām, āvyā chhabīlojī Chhāṇī gām; <RHYME_21>
Mūkyu Shiyājie tyā sāmaiyu, banī shobhā jāy nahi kahiyu.  <RHYME_21>
transliteration.context: A pair of lovers, Shyam and Chhani, are separated by fate, their love remaining unfulfilled. Their union is not meant to be, leaving only sorrow in its place.

transliteration.couplet:
Āvyā pāyagā pāḷā apār, sāmā shaṇagāryā gaj chār; <RHYME_22>
Te upar ambāḍī jarinī, sahi shobhā kahu hu Harinī.  <RHYME_22>
transliteration.context: The couplet speaks of a person's wealth and success being like the great Himalayas, with their good deeds and virtues towering above others. The second line suggests that one should consider themselves fortunate to be blessed by God.

transliteration.couplet:
Chitra vichitra bhātyane range, shobhe hastī vasan sorange; <RHYME_23>
Vaḷī ūnṭ shaṇagārī sārā, dharyā te par moṭā nagārā.  <RHYME_23>
transliteration.context: The colorful and strange things happen, and the beautiful Hasti's house is full of ornaments; similarly, my village is filled with many beautiful things.

transliteration.couplet:
Bījā ghālyā chhe ghoḍe ānak, banī joyā sarakhī bānak; <RHYME_24>
Paḍe nagāre dhrosh dhīmerī, shobhe nejā nishāṇ naferī.  <RHYME_24>
transliteration.context: A seed sown in the right season will flourish and bear fruit, just like a lamp lit at the right time will shine brightly. Similarly, a wise person's guidance can illuminate others' paths only if they are receptive to it.

transliteration.couplet:
Vāje paḍagham bheḷī vānsaḷī, bher bhūngaḷ ne truī vaḷī; <RHYME_25>
Bole sharaṇāī sware sārī, vāje vājā te mangaḷkārī.  <RHYME_25>
transliteration.context:
Life's journey is like a wild elephant ride, unpredictable and uncontrollable.
One should surrender to the situation, just as an elephant tamer controls the animal with gentle gestures.

transliteration.couplet:
Rath velya gāḍī ghaṇī menā, āvyā sāmaiye samūh tenā; <RHYME_26>
Banī shobhā sāmaiyānī bahu, suṇī lok āvyā sāmā sahu.  <RHYME_26>
transliteration.context:
The summary is:

A beautiful gathering takes place at the riverbank, with people from far and wide coming together; its beauty is seen by all.

(Note: I've kept it brief as per your request!)

transliteration.couplet:
Āvī lāgyā Prabhujīne pāy, nīrkhe Nāth harakh na māy; <RHYME_27>
Kahe sahu joḍī em hāth, āvo beso ambāḍīe Nāth.  <RHYME_27>
transliteration.context: One's path is guided by the Almighty, and one should not be deluded by maya (illusion); hold on to the Lord with your hands and feet.

transliteration.couplet:
Dayā karī diyo darashan, karo Prabhujī shaher pāvan; <RHYME_28>
Pachhī kṛupā karīne kṛupāḷu, beṭhā dantī upar dayāḷu.  <RHYME_28>
transliteration.context: Show mercy and glance upon the Prabhu's city; may compassion arise from it and cover all faults with its kindness.

transliteration.couplet:
Nārupant Nānā beṭhā sāthe, kare chamar Nāthne māthe; <RHYME_29>
Banī shobhā jāy nahi kaī, jai jai shabda rahyo tiyā thaī.  <RHYME_29>
transliteration.context: In a small village, the lord's shadow falls with the master, and his devotee's voice rises to the sky.

transliteration.couplet:
Karyā darashan sahu dāse, nīrkhī pūrī karī man āshe; <RHYME_30>
Beṭhā bīje gaje sant chār, sange Ayodhyāvāsī udār.  <RHYME_30>
transliteration.context: A humble servant sees the glory of action and is filled with devotion in their heart; they sow seeds on earth and reap a harvest, just like a saint from Ayodhya.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī dhīre dhīre shu chālatā, āvyā Nāth darshan ālatā; <RHYME_31>
Zānz mṛudang laī manḍaḷī, gāy gavaiyā vadhāī vaḷī.  <RHYME_31>
transliteration.context: Slowly and steadily, the path unfolds, revealing the divine vision. In this moment of joy, I dance with my soul, expressing gratitude to the Lord.

transliteration.couplet:
Āvyā shahermā Shrī Mahārāj, bahu jīvnā karavā kāj; <RHYME_32>
Juve amṛut najare Nāth, vaḷī joḍe chhe sahune hāth.  <RHYME_32>
transliteration.context: The king of the universe, Lord Mahārāj, performs countless tasks in many lifetimes; His divine hand holds the thread of fate for each individual to weave their own destiny.

transliteration.couplet:
Nar-nārī je shahernā jan, nīrkhī Nāthne thayā pāvan; <RHYME_33>
Ek pṛuthavī ne traṇ māḷe, chaḍī lok Nāthne nihāḷe.  <RHYME_33>
transliteration.context:
The couplet describes the beauty of nature and the blessings of God, where even a small drop of water (nar) can quench one's thirst.

In this paradise-like world, one's soul is lifted by the divine.

transliteration.couplet:
Nar-nārī karī darshan, kare kar joḍīne stavan; <RHYME_34>
Nīlī pīlī paherī lāl sāḍī, shobhe fūlī jem fūlvāḍī.  <RHYME_34>
transliteration.context: A soul (nar-nari) seeks spiritual fulfillment by performing acts of devotion and singing prayers. The path to enlightenment is adorned with the beauty of spiritual growth, like a lotus flower blooming in its natural environment.

transliteration.couplet:
Em banī bajār ne sherī, sahunī najar Nāth par ṭherī; <RHYME_35>
Jem chitramā lakhyā chitāre, nīrkhī manuṣhya maṭaku na māre.  <RHYME_35>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes the beauty of a woman's eyes, saying they are like a picture that surpasses all human imagination. The comparison is so vivid that it can't be contained by mortal boundaries.

transliteration.couplet:
Joī Mohanne man mohyu, notu jovu teṇe paṇ joyu; <RHYME_36>
Em sahunā līdhā chitta chorī, kare kem jene hāth dorī.  <RHYME_36>
transliteration.context: The couplet says that when the mind is in love, one becomes one with it, and even worries are forgotten. It also mentions that when the heart is filled with love, all sorrows disappear.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī āvyā purpati pās, nīrkhyā Shiyājīe Avināsh; <RHYME_37>
Pachhī padharāvyā havelī māy, karī danḍavat lāgyo pāy.  <RHYME_37>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a person who has achieved spiritual freedom and is now dwelling in the divine realm, beyond worldly concerns. This state of liberation allows them to experience pure joy and inner peace, unshackled by material attachments.

transliteration.couplet:
Tyāre Hari maḷyā grahī hāthe, karī moṭī maher ene māthe; <RHYME_38>
Pachhī prīte pāṭ ḍhāḷyo rāje, Shrī Mahārājne besavā kāje.  <RHYME_38>
transliteration.context: Lord Hari takes away the worries of those who seek him; in His love, even the most turbulent situations become calm and peaceful.

transliteration.couplet:
Te upar beṭhā Hari āpe, baḷyā pāpiyā potāne pāpe; <RHYME_39>
Karī prītyeshu pūjyā rājane, pūjī Prabhu pāmyo mod mane.  <RHYME_39>
transliteration.context: One's good deeds go up to God, while bad deeds are stored in the storehouse of karma. With love and devotion, one worships the Lord and finds joy in their own mind.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī ūbho āgye joḍī hāth, kahe dhanya dhanya mārā Nāth; <RHYME_40>
Āj thayā mane darashan, koīk pūrva janamne puṇya.  <RHYME_40>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a devotee's gratitude towards their Lord, who has shown them mercy and saved them from previous life's karma. The devotee is blessed to have had a darshan (divine encounter) with God in this lifetime, which is a rare privilege.

transliteration.couplet:
Em kahī lāgyo pāy vaḷī, thayā rājī te Nāth sāmbhaḷī; <RHYME_41>
Pachhī padhāryā shahermā Shyām, karyā anek jīvnā kām.  <RHYME_41>
transliteration.context:
The couplet conveys the idea that one should strive to be humble and content with what they have, just like a peacock is satisfied with its own beauty.

It encourages striving for a life of simplicity and contentment, rather than constantly seeking more.

transliteration.couplet:
Farī darshan sahune dīdhā, bahu jan kṛutārath kīdhā; <RHYME_42>
Pachhī padhāryā Nāth utāre, chālyo mahīpati morya tyāre.  <RHYME_42>
transliteration.context: A virtuous person's true nature is revealed when faced with adversity, and their kindness towards others becomes apparent. Their Lord takes them away at the right time, and they go to their heavenly abode.

transliteration.couplet:
Kāju tambu kanātya rāvaṭī, karī ūbhī soyak sāmaṭī; <RHYME_43>
Tiyā utaryā dīndayāḷ, rāye jamavā karāvyo thāḷ.  <RHYME_43>
transliteration.context: A wise old woman's words are sweet and gentle, like a ripe mango. She speaks softly to calm the worries of those around her.

transliteration.couplet:
Paṭhī nij sambandhīne hāthe, karyā sundar bhojan Nāthe; <RHYME_44>
Pachhī beṭhā sinhāsane Shyām, āvyu darshane saghaḷu gām.  <RHYME_44>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a simple meal prepared with one's own hands as the most beautiful feast, and not depending on others for it. It also mentions that even in a humble dwelling like Shyama's ashram, one can find peace and unity with others.

transliteration.couplet:
Sonā rūpā taṇā fūl laī, āvī vadhāve vālāne kaī; <RHYME_45>
Bahu lāve chhe fūlnā hār, liye prīteshu prāṇ-ādhār.  <RHYME_45>
transliteration.context:
A lovely couplet! Here's a summary:

Bring the beauty (sona) and fragrance (fūl), but be prepared to face challenges; even if you gain everything, it's all based on love and life's foundation.

transliteration.couplet:
Mīṭhā mevā ne sundar faḷ, lāve dūdh penḍā kaī daḷ; <RHYME_46>
Ṭhāle hāthe Nāth pāse nāve, nāḷī keḷī ikṣhu ādi lāve.  <RHYME_46>
transliteration.context: A beautiful wife makes a sweet husband's day with her tender care, just as she would prepare milk to make yogurt. Just as the lord of the forest (Nath) has a boat that takes him across, so too does a loving couple have a journey together.

transliteration.couplet:
Moṭā moṭā je shahermā hatā, te paṇ āvyā chhe hāth joḍatā; <RHYME_47>
Ati sārmith joī apār, joḍī hāth name nar-nārya.  <RHYME_47>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a situation where one's pride and ego lead to misfortune, as if holding onto a handful of sand that keeps slipping away. It also warns that excessive pride can lead to downfall, like a ship without anchor or direction.

transliteration.couplet:
Em namāvī sahune shīsh, ūṭhyā jīt karī Jagdīsh; <RHYME_48>
Āvī utāre poḍhiyā Nāth, bahu jīvne karī sanāth.  <RHYME_48>
transliteration.context: One's own family is a great victory, and it's won with the Lord's help; similarly, one's own self is a great wealth, and it's acquired with the Creator's care.

transliteration.couplet:
Sarve sant chhe potāne sāthe, jamyā karī rasoī te hāthe; <RHYME_49>
Vuṭho ati tiyā varasāt, em karatā thayu parabhāt.  <RHYME_49>
transliteration.context: All saints are together in heaven, with God as their host, and their joy is in the Lord's hand.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī jāgiyā jīvanprāṇ, karavā bahu jīvnā kalyāṇ; <RHYME_50>
Dīdhā darshan sahune Shyāme, nīrkhyā nayaṇā bharī sahu gāme.  <RHYME_50>
transliteration.context: A life well-lived is the greatest blessing, and one's actions should be good enough to be remembered by others after they're gone. One should strive to achieve a glimpse of heaven while still alive, and fill their life with sweet memories like a field filled with blooming flowers.

transliteration.couplet:
Thāy uttar ne prashna bahu, jāṇe jīt Swāmījīnī sahu; <RHYME_51>
Em sarvene pāchherā pāḍī, vāt potānī satya dekhāḍī.  <RHYME_51>
transliteration.context: A seeker asks the right question to their master, who then reveals the truth with perfect timing. The answer is revealed only when the seeker has prepared themselves and is ready to receive it.

transliteration.couplet:
Matpanth taṇu mān haryu, satya vachan Shrī Swāmīnu karyu; <RHYME_52>
Je kahyutu Swāmī Rāmānande, rahī Dhorājī māhi ānande.  <RHYME_52>
transliteration.context: The path of truth is shown by God, and it's our duty to follow. Our Lord Rama's name brings joy and takes us back to our home.

transliteration.couplet:
Bhekh khapashe sahu khaḷatāḷe, karyu vachan satya dayāḷe; <RHYME_53>
Em vītī gayā din traṇ, pachhī padhāryā asharaṇ sharaṇ.  <RHYME_53>
transliteration.context:
A lie told in haste is soon revealed, but a true promise brings solace and comfort.
Even the darkest day will pass, and one will find shelter from troubles.

transliteration.couplet:
Jevī rītyanu sāmaiyu lāvyā, tethī vīsheke vaḷāvā āvyā; <RHYME_54>
Vaḷī padharāvyā rāye gherya, karī prītye pūjā bahu perya.  <RHYME_54>
transliteration.context: A pair of lovers meets in the evening, their love growing stronger with each passing moment; they worship and celebrate their love with great fervor.

transliteration.couplet:
Sāro poshāg shirapech jeh, āpyo nareshe Nāthne teh; <RHYME_55>
Vaḷī kahe chhe vāramvār, vahelā āvajyo prāṇ-ādhār.  <RHYME_55>
transliteration.context:
The devotee's soul is consumed by the Lord, and worldly attachments are left behind; their consciousness is firmly rooted in the divine.

In this life, they speak of worldly desires, but in their next breath, their spirit soars towards their creator.

transliteration.couplet:
Jyāre teḍāvu vinati karī, tyāre vahelā padhārajyo Hari; <RHYME_56>
Pachhī Nāth kahe teḍasho tame, jāṇo jarūr āvashu ame.  <RHYME_56>
transliteration.context: A devotee is eager to serve the Lord, just like a king's loyal servant waits for instructions; The Nath (Lord) says, "You are worthy of my love, know this and come soon."

transliteration.couplet:
Em kahīne ūṭhyā dayāḷ, tyāre bhāveshu bheṭyā bhūpāḷ; <RHYME_57>
Pachhī shīkh māgī chālyā Shyām, beṭhā ambāḍīye sukhdhām.  <RHYME_57>
transliteration.context: Merciful are those who show pity on the weak, and their deeds are remembered for centuries. Shyam, go beyond the sea of thorns and find eternal happiness in the land of peace.

transliteration.couplet:
Detā sahune darshan dān, āvyā shaher bahārā Bhagwān; <RHYME_58>
Gaj bāj vājintra apār, āvyā vaḷāvavā nar-nārya.  <RHYME_58>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes the joy and excitement of seeing a loved one after a long time, likening it to experiencing the beauty of spring in the city. It's a celebration of reunions and the happiness they bring.

transliteration.couplet:
Teh sarvene shīkh ja dīdhī, evī līlā Vaḍodare kīdhī; <RHYME_59>
Pachhī ghoḍe thayā asavār, āvyā Sānkardā gām mozār.  <RHYME_59>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a whimsical ride in Vadodara's amusement park where the joy of playtime brings together people from different backgrounds and professions. The poem rhymes and uses wordplay to convey the excitement and unity among the riders.

transliteration.couplet:
Tyāthī vālo āvyā Varatāl, karī līlā alaukik lāl; <RHYME_60>
Doḍh mās lagī tiyā rahyā, nij sambandhī Gaḍhaḍe gayā.  <RHYME_60>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a play (lila) that transcends the ordinary world, where love is so profound it seems to bind people in a divine manner. The second line suggests that this love has a deep connection with one's inner self, which is revealed through the passage of time.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī Shikṣhāpatrī lakhī sārī, āpī satasangīne sukhkārī; <RHYME_61>
Tyāthī padhāryā sundar Shyām, guṇsāgar Gaḍhaḍe gām.  <RHYME_61>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a seeker who has gained spiritual wisdom and finds joy in the company of saints.

transliteration.couplet:
Karyo utsav em Jīvane, Kārtik vadi trīj dane; <RHYME_62>
Te di karī Vaḍodare līlā, hatā sant satasangī bheḷā.  <RHYME_62>
transliteration.context: The festival of life is celebrated in every moment, and the playfulness of Kartik's moon is enjoyed by all; even a sinner can find divine company.
